title-group.article-title: Splenocolonic fistula following non-operative management of splenic rupture

abstract.p: Non-operative management has become the preferred treatment for splenic trauma in the absence of haemodynamic instability. The reported complications of non-operative management of splenic trauma may include pseudoaneurysm formation, delayed splenic rupture and splenic abscess formation. Splenocolonic fistula is a finding that has only previously been described in association with Crohn’s disease, pancreatitis, malignancy and haematological disorders. We present the case of a 16-year-old male who suffered a blunt traumatic injury to the spleen, was haemodynamically stable and successfully managed non-operatively. He represented 1 month later following a single episode of per-rectum bleeding. A CT scan of his abdomen revealed a pseudoaneurysm within the spleen, a splenic abscess and a splenocolonic fistula. He proceeded to emergency laparotomy for splenectomy and colonic resection and had an uneventful recovery. The history of management of blunt traumatic splenic injury is discussed, along with the associated risks of operative and conservative management. Methods predicting the success of non-operative management are explored, along with their application and relevance to this particular case.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Splenic preservation is the preferred method of management of blunt splenic injury in the patient without haemodynamic compromise (Velhamos et al., 2003), a course of management that has evolved primarily as a result of understanding of the immunological complications associated with splenectomy (King and Schumacher, 1952). There are of course risks associated with non-operative management of blunt splenic injury, including development of haemodynamic instability, delayed rupture, cystic evolution of subcapsular haematoma, pseudoaneurysm formation and splenic abscess. We describe a complication not previously described following the non-operative management of a traumatic splenic rupture – formation of a splenocolonic fistula.

sec.title: Case report
sec.p: A 16-year-old male with no prior medical or surgical history was transferred via helicopter to a tertiary referral hospital in Australia with blunt abdominal trauma following a motorcycle accident where he was thrown forward over the handlebars at a speed of 60 km/h. There was no loss of consciousness and although initially winded, he did not present to his regional emergency department for a number of hours.

On arrival at the tertiary hospital, his heart rate (HR) was 110, blood pressure (BP) was 110/60 and abdominal examination revealed generalised tenderness; a Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) scan was positive. As he was haemodynamically stable with a systolic BP of 110, he proceeded to a computed tomographic (CT) scan of chest, abdomen and pelvis. This demonstrated a Grade IV (AAST classification) splenic injury, with no active contrast extravasation or pseudoaneurysm formation, and a Grade III (AAST classification) segment V liver laceration with a large haemoperitoneum. There were no other injuries identified in any of the other solid or hollow organs on this CT scan.

Although tachycardic, he maintained a systolic BP above 100, and his haemoglobin did not fall and so was managed conservatively and monitored in a high-dependency unit. A repeat CT scan of his abdomen at Day three following the injury showed no change to the appearance of the splenic laceration or the haemoperitoneum, and the liver laceration had become less appreciable. The patient was discharged to the care of his parents after 11 days.

One month after discharge, the patient represented to hospital following a single episode of bright red bleeding per rectum of approximately 200 ml earlier that day. He had been well up until this point with no other symptoms. His HR and BP were normal and his abdominal examination was unremarkable. A CT scan of his abdomen demonstrated a splenic abscess with an associated splenic pseudoaneurysm and a possible communication between the abscess and the splenic flexure of the colon (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Abdominal CT, coronal view. (A) Splenic pseudoaneurysm. (B) Communicating fistula between splenic abscess and splenic flexure of colon.

The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy, which revealed multiple dense inflammatory adhesions surrounding the splenic abscess and a fistula between the splenic abscess and the splenic flexure of the colon (Figure 2). A splenectomy was performed together with segmental colonic resection of the splenic flexure. A side-to-side hand-sewn double layered colonic anastomosis was performed. The patient made an uneventful recovery and was discharged home 7 days following his operation. Figure 2.
Pathological specimens. (A) Spleen: Splenic abscess and site of communicating fistula. (B) Splenic flexure of colon: Communicating fistula.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Contemporary splenic surgery began in 1892 after the report of the first successful splenectomy of a traumatic closed rupture of the spleen (Riegner, 1893). Splenectomy became routine for splenic injuries until the 1950s when overwhelming post splenectomy infection (OPSI) was recognised in children (King and Schumacher, 1952). The non-surgical approach to splenic injury found traction in 1968 when The Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto published its experience using a conservative approach to paediatric splenic injuries (Upadhyaya and Simpson, 1968). These results were applied to adults and became popular through the 1980s and is now regarded as the standard of care (Lutzker and Chun, 1981; Villalba et al., 1990).

Currently, the decision to proceed to splenectomy following injury is governed primarily by the patient's haemodynamic status (Velhamos et al., 2003) with the only absolute indication for emergency splenectomy after trauma being haemodynamic compromise. Other factors such as presence of active contrast extravasation on imaging, pseudoaneurysm formation, ability to perform splenic artery embolisation, associated penetrating injuries, clinical or radiological suspicion of another intra-abdominal injury, failure of non-operative management (ongoing transfusion requirement), or associated significant head injury, must also be taken into consideration when making this decision (Finch and Banting, 2004).

Complications following emergency splenectomy for trauma are well described. The risk of OPSI is 0.23–0.42% per year (Ejstrud et al., 2000), with a lifetime risk of 5% (Lynch and Kapila, 1996) and mortality risk of 38–69% (Waghorn, 2001). This risk is increased in children (Lucas, 1991), those who have received immunosuppressive treatment (Coleman et al., 1983) and when splenectomy is performed for haematological disorders (Styrt, 1990).

Well-described complications following non-operative management of splenic injury include pseudoaneurysm formation (Schurr et al., 1995) and delayed rupture, even up to 5½ years later (Deva and Thompson, 1996); splenic abscess formation is also well recognised (Nores et al., 1998). Although splenocolonic fistulae have been described in the literature in association with Crohn's disease (Pappalardo et al., 2007), pancreatitis (Goldsmith et al., 2011), melanoma (Chun et al., 1997) and haematological disorders (Naschitz et al., 1986; Means et al., 2003), it has not been described following non-operative management of splenic injury. The case discussed here details a Grade IV splenic rupture in an adolescent who was managed non-operatively because he was haemodynamically stable. The patient proceeded to develop a pseudoaneurysm, splenic abscess and splenocolonic fistula. In isolation these complications are rare, but to establish all three is certainly exceptional.

Causes of delayed or uncommon complications related to non-operative management of abdominal trauma have been described as an abnormal or insufficient healing process, retention of necrotic tissue, secondary infection of previously sterile collections and underestimated injury severity (Goffette and Laterre, 2003). Even though this splenocolonic fistula may have formed as the result of intra-abdominal infection or inflammation, the precise mechanism of its development is uncertain. Despite an initial CT scan that did not demonstrate an injury to the splenic flexure of the colon, it is possible that this may have been missed. The ability of CT scan to detect serosal or full thickness injuries to the colon in the setting of trauma is limited, unless there is obvious free gas. The clinical condition of this patient in the 11 days following his initial accident did not demonstrate symptoms or signs consistent with a colonic injury. Similarly, he did not manifest any evidence of sepsis or impairment of bowel function in the weeks following discharge from hospital.

The role of serial imaging with either ultrasound or CT scan following blunt splenic trauma is equivocal. Some centres advocate Doppler ultrasound at regular intervals until complete resolution is seen following blunt splenic injury in children (Dombremez et al., 2006; Safavi et al., 2011); however, the evidence that this influences the management of patients is limited. Similarly, there is no evidence that serial CT scans without good clinical indication influences either the outcome or management of patients with blunt splenic trauma, although this is often practiced and reported (Goldstein et al., 1985; Sherman et al., 1994; Allins et al., 1996; Lawson et al., 1995; Weinberg et al., 2007; Weinberg et al., 2010). Demonstration of contrast extravasation on CT at presentation was believed to predict the failure of non-operative management (Schurr et al., 1995); and based on this finding, aggressive surveillance for splenic artery pseudoaneurysm (and subsequent embolisation) was reported to improve the success rate of non-operative management (Davis et al, 1998). In the case reported here, a CT scan performed 2–3 weeks after the initial injury may have detected a pseudoaneurysm or splenic abscess, however, the necessity for a splenectomy may not have changed. Furthermore, with regard to bed rest and restricted physical activity, there is no good evidence that either is necessary or beneficial, or that they improve the success of non-operative management of blunt splenic injury (Meredith et al., 1994; Croce et al., 1995).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This is the first reported case in the published literature of a splenocolonic fistula following blunt splenic injury. Although very rare, complications of non-operative management of blunt splenic injuries need to be considered and weighed against the postoperative complications of splenectomy, such as OPSI, when deciding whether a patient requires splenectomy for trauma. The role of follow-up imaging in blunt splenic injuries is limited. There is no doubt that serial CT scans will detect the presence of a splenic pseudoaneurysm, however, routine follow-up imaging of all adult patients with CT scan has not been shown to influence outcome or management. If clinically indicated or if contrast extravasation is present on initial CT scan, follow up CT scan may aid in the detection of complications requiring a change in management.
